caption:
The photograph features two men, closely positioned in front of the camera and looking directly into the lens. Both men are dressed in cold-weather attire. The man on the left wears yellow-tinted goggles and a black-and-white checked jacket with a visible patch, suggesting a uniform or team outfit. He also has a black beanie under his goggles and seems to be wearing suspenders over a light-colored shirt. The man on the right also sports yellow-tinted goggles and a similar black-and-white checkered pom-pom beanie. He wears a blue jacket atop a shirt, visible near his neck.

These men appear to be engaged in a winter outdoor activity, as indicated by their clothing and the snowy backdrop consisting of dense, snow-covered trees. Between them, a metal frame, possibly part of a sled or outdoor equipment, is visible. The environment suggests a cold, wintry setting, possibly during a sporting or research event.

Their expressions are serious, and they seem to be focused on something off-camera or possibly interacting with the photographer, which adds an intimate, candid quality to the capture. The close-up framing emphasizes their faces and attire, reflecting a purposeful outing or adventure in the snow.
title: Members of the Crag Rats Climbing Club make winter snow surveys for the U.S. Soil Conservation Service at Tilly Jane Camp Ground on Mt. Hood. Authorities can then anticipate the effect of spring thaw on the Columbia River.
